The primary goal was to calculate the difference between the lowest sell price on one exchange and the highest buy price on another and execute trades when the spread exceeded transaction fees.

title: Data Visualization
text:
I developed a stock analysis dashboard to monitor market volatility, specifically focusing on the analysis of AAPL stock performance. I created this dashboard to identify market momentum; I wanted to create a tool that could visually signal high-probability trading windows by processing complex price data in real-time. My rationale for this specific layout is to use a candlestick chart with a MACD indicator which indicates good entry points.



AAPL Stock Analysis Chart



Quantitative Market Data
To support the visual analysis, the table below provides a granular view of the raw numerical values processed by the dashboard during a specific trading window. This data allows for a detailed audit of the signals seen in the visual chart.

Technical Challenges and Rationale
Developing this stock analysis dashboard presented several technical hurdles, particularly in managing high-frequency data streams to ensure the MACD and candlestick layers remained synchronized during periods of high volatility. I specifically chose the Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicator because it provides a reliable measure of momentum and trend direction, which is essential for identifying high-probability entry points in a stock like AAPL. By analyzing the relationship between two moving averages of prices, the MACD allowed the system to filter out market noise and focus on genuine trend reversals.
Integrating an interactive data table was a strategic choice to satisfy the requirement for sharing quantitative data in a structured format. While the chart provides a high-level visual summary, the data table allows for a granular inspection of the raw numerical values, such as the exact opening and closing prices that form each candlestick. This dual-layer approach ensures that the visualization is not purely artistic but serves as a functional tool for data-driven storytelling, allowing users to verify the trends seen in the graph against the actual underlying figures.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
What is the GenAI tool you have used? Why did you choose it?
I used Gemini to assist me with this lab because of its ability to process screenshots of my RStudio environment and provide real-time troubleshooting for Quarto website configuration.



How did the GenAI tool help you in completing the assessment?
The tool helped me polish up my writing and also helped me to troubleshoot errors.



What do you think are beneficial about the tool?
It is extremely beneficial for debugging syntax errors in YAML and Markdown that are easy to miss manually. It allowed me to focus on the content while it handled the repetitive formatting tasks.



What do you think are challenging about the tool?
The main challenge was ensuring the AI understood my specific file paths and naming conventions; I had to be very precise about naming my files (like Data Visualization.qmd) to get the right advice.



How do you think GenAI tools will assist you for your future study or work?
In the future, I see these tools as essential for rapid prototyping and learning new coding frameworks. They can help bridge the gap between having a technical idea and presenting it professionally on a digital platform.

title: Trading bot Project
text:
Developed an Arbitrage Trading Bot designed to identify and utilize price discrepancies for the same asset across different cryptocurrency exchanges. The primary goal was to calculate the difference between the lowest sell price on one exchange and the highest buy price on another and execute trades when the spread exceeded transaction fees.






Binance







Crypto.com





Developing the arbitrage trading bot presented several complex technical hurdles that required a disciplined approach to overcome. One of the most persistent issues involved managing API rate limits on platforms like Binance and Crypto.com, where frequent data requests often triggered temporary IP bans and forced the development of more efficient polling intervals. Beyond connectivity, the project faced significant execution latency challenges, as the narrow profit margins in arbitrage often vanished in milliseconds before a trade could be finalized. Furthermore, calculating true profitability proved difficult because the algorithm had to be constantly refined to account for hidden costs such as exchange trading fees, withdrawal taxes, and market slippage. These obstacles highlighted the necessity of rigorous data cleaning and naming convention mapping to ensure that identical assets were accurately tracked across different exchange environments.
